Andra typer av jäst eller mjölksyrabakterier åstadkommer då den syrliga karaktären. Ett tredje sätt att erhålla syrlighet är att lagra det utjästa ölet en längre tid i träfat där syrabildande mikroorganismer kan tränga in.
-K0gUAEYI1pSlFaKZroD.name: Syrliga öl

styles.appearance: Halmgul till bärnstensfärgad,ofta disig.
styles.aroma: Friskt syrlig med toner av stall och kompost. Kan ha inslag av grapefrukt, rabarber, moget äpple, trä, jord eller getost. Blir med lagring vinös och moget fruktig. Bör inte upplevas som stickigt sur. Ingen doft av färsk humle. Ingen diacetyl smörkola.
styles.description: Traditionell lambik (franska: lambic) är ett spontanjäst öl bryggt som bryggs på kornmalt och 30-40 % omältat vete. Ölet jäses i ett eller flera år. Hembryggare efterliknar ofta spontanjäsninggenom att tillsätta flera jäst- och bakteriestammar, normalt en kombination av saccharomyces- och brettanomycesjäst samt mjölksyrabakterier. Dessutom används humle som oxiderats under en längre tid och tappat sin bitterhet men fortfarande har kvar sina antiseptiskaegenskaper. Resultatet blir ett syrligt, torrt och komplext öl.
styles.examples: Cantillon Grand Cru Bruocsella.
styles.flavor: Ung lambik är torr och syrlig med tonerav äppelcider, grapefrukt eller rabarber. Oxiderad humle ger obetydlig konventionell humlebeska men träiga toner som i kombinationmed syran kan upplevas som beska. Stalltonerhör till smakbilden. Blir med lagring vinösoch moget fruktig. Ättiksyra får finnas på förnimbara nivåer men en lambik bör inte upplevassom vinägeraktigt hård sur.
styles.name: Lambik
styles.texture: Syrlig och torr. Mycket låg till mediumkolsyra.

styles.appearance: Halmgul till bärnstensfärgad, ofta disig. Kraftigt, vitt, moussigt skum.
styles.aroma: Friskt syrlig med toner av stall och kompost. Kan ha inslag av grapefrukt, rabarber, moget äpple, trä, jord eller getost. Blir med lagring vinös och moget fruktig. Bör inte upplevas som stickigt sur. Ingen doft av färsk humle. Ingen diacetyl smörkola.
styles.description: Traditionell geuze (franska: gueuze) är en blandning av ett- och fleråriga lambik som får efterjäsa på flaska. Med sin stora kolyra och sitt moussiga vita skum kallas geuze ibland för ölets champagne.
styles.examples: Cantillon Gueuze, Oud Beersel Oude Geuze, Boon Oude Geuze, Boon Oude Geuze Mariage Parfait.
styles.flavor: Ung geuze är torr och syrlig med toner av äppelcider, grapefrukt eller rabarber. Oxiderad humle ger obetydlig konventionell humlebeska men träiga toner som i kombination med syran kan upplevas som beska. Stalltoner skall höra till smakbilden. Blir med lagring vinös och moget fruktig. Ättiksyra får finnas på förnimbara nivåer men en geuze bör inte upplevas som vinägeraktigt sur.
styles.name: Gueze
styles.texture: Syrlig och torr. Kraftig kolsyra.

styles.appearance: Färgen kommer i allmänhet från frukten, men svagt färgad frukt har mindre påverkan på utseendet. Äldre exemplar kan bli brunaktiga eller blekna. Kraftigt skum.
styles.aroma: Frukten skall kännas tydligt. I övrigt friskt syrlig med toner av stall och kompost. Kan ha inslag av trä, jord eller getost. Äldre exemplar är ofta mindre tydliga i sin fruktkaraktär. Bör inte upplevas som stickigt sur. Ingen doft av färsk humle. Ingen diacetyl smörkola.
styles.description: Tradionell fruktlambik erhålls genom att låta lambik jäsa en andra gång med tillsats av frukt eller bär. Vanligast är surkörsbär (kriek) eller hallon (frambozen), men andra frukter eller bär förekommer. Fruktdoseringen varierar mellan 150 g l och 350 g l beroende på hur koncentrerad frukten är i smaken. Vid inlämning i denna klass skall bryggaren ange vilken frukt som använts. Denna definition beskriver den klassiska syrligare öltypen. Moderna, sötade varianter skall i stället lämnas in i underklassen Övriga klassiska syrliga öl.
styles.examples: Cantillon Kriek, Cantillon Lamvinus (Merlot-druva), Cantillon Vigneronne (Muscat-druva), Lindemans Cuvé René Kriek, Boon Oude Kriek, Boon Framboise Mariage Parfait, De Cam Oude Kriek, Drie Fonteinen Kriek, Girardin Kriek, Hansen Oude Kriek, Oud Beersel Kriek, Mort Subite Kriek.
styles.flavor: Frukten skall kännas tydligt och harmonisera med syror, trä-, och stalltoner. I äldre exemplar blir fruktsmaken mindre tydlig. Ättiksyra får finnas på förnimbara nivåer, men en fruktlambik bör inte upplevas som vinägeraktigt sur.
styles.name: Fruktlambik
styles.texture: Syrlig och torr. Kraftig kolsyra.

styles.appearance: Nötbrun till mörkt rödbrun.
styles.aroma: Domineras av malt och fruktestrar. Malten kan ge toner av karamell, mörk sirap eller choklad. Fruktestrarna påminner ofta om russin, plommon, fikon, dadlar eller svarta vinbär. Kan vara lätt fenoliskt kryddig. Ekfatslagring kan ge vaniljtoner. Sherrytoner förekommer ofta i lagrade exemplar. Syrliga toner ska finnas men bör ej upplevas som vinägeraktigt. Ingen humlearom. Diacetyl smörkola kan förekomma på låga nivåer.
styles.description: Oud bruin jäses med en kombination av överjäst och syrabildande bakterier. I vissa fall tillsätts syrakulturen avsiktligt, i andra fall kommer den av flera års lagring i gamla ekfat. Ibland kan Brettanomyces-jäst bidra med stalltoner. För att balansera syran tillsätter man ibland oförjäsbara sockerarter. Detta kan även bidra till en större kropp.
styles.examples: Rodenbach Klassiek, Rodenbach Grand Cru, Bios Vlaamse Bourgogne, Liefmans Goudenband.
styles.flavor: Domineras av malt och fruktighet. Frukttonerna påminner ofta om plommon, röda vinbär, russin, fikon, dadlar, svarta körsbär eller katrinplommon. Maltkaraktären påminner ofta om karamell, toffee, mörk sirap och choklad. Skall ha en märkbar syrlighet som inte får vara påtagligt ättiks- eller vinägersyrlig. Syrligheten tillsammans med sherryaktiga lagringstoner ger ofta en söt-syrlighet i ölet. En viss humlebeska är tillåten, dock skall ingen smak- eller aromhumle finnas. Kan ha en friskt syrlig torr eftersmak som inte får bli astringent.
styles.name: Oud bruin
styles.texture: Medium kropp. Låg till medium kolsyra.

styles.appearance: Mycket ljust halmgul. Allt från klar till lätt disig. Dålig skumstabilitet på grund av den höga syran, låga proteinhalten och avsaknad av humle. Skall vara champagnelikt mousserande.
styles.aroma: Tydlig mjölksyradoft. Kan ha fruktiga eller blommiga toner som växer med lagring. En lätt nyans av stalltoner från brettanomyces finns i vissa exemplar. Ingen humle, diacetyl smörkola eller DMS.
styles.description: En lätt och uppfriskande specialitet från Berlin. Serveras ofta med tillsats av söt fruktsirap (mit Schuss), eller blandas med pilsner för balansera den tydliga syran. Bryggs ofta med 50% vetemalt och lika mycket pilsnermalt. Jäses med en kombination av överjäst och mjölksyrabakterier. Napoleons trupper kallade denna öl för 'Champagnen från norr', på grund av dess livliga och eleganta karaktär.
styles.examples: Berliner Kindl 2,5%.
styles.flavor: Mjölksyra dominerar. Ofta förekommer en brödig vetesmak. Humlebeskan skall vara mycket låg. Lätta stalltoner från Brettanomyces kan förekomma. Varken humlesmak, diacetyl smörkola eller DMS.
styles.name: Berliner weisse
styles.texture: Lätt kropp. Mycket torr i eftersmaken. Mycket hög kolsyrehalt.

styles.description: Här lämnas syrligt öl in som saknar definition ovan. Såväl klassiska öltyper som experimentbrygder kan förekomma. På grund av den stora variationen ges ingen typdefinition. Bryggaren skall tydligt ange vilken typ som avses, gärna bifoga en beskrivning av öltypen från öllitteraturen och om möjligt ge kommersiella exempel.
styles.examples: Följande icke fullständiga lista ger exempel på övrigt klassiskt syrligt öl:  Humlat spontanjäst öl. Cantillon Iris. Faro - lambik som sötats med mörkt socker inför servering. Sötad fruktlambik.Lindemans kriek. Oud bruin vrucht - oud bruin efterjäst med frukt som körsbär eller hallon. Syrlig engelsk stock ale.Prize Old Ale.
styles.name: Övriga klassiska syrliga öl

-K0gUAEbwyYSh9PQ2_v-.description: Klass D-K avser klasiska öltyper som ej finns upptagna under annan huvud- eller underkategori. Andra typer kan förekomma. Specificera på bryggprotokollet vilken typ som avses samt gärna en referens till literatur och eller till ett kommerciellt exempel.
-K0gUAEbwyYSh9PQ2_v-.name: Specialöl

styles.description: Ett öl där man tillsatt frukt, bär eller grönsaker i kok, primär eller sekundärjäsningen, som ger en tydlig men balanserad frukt eller grönsakskaraktär. Dessa öl skall inte domineras av humle.
styles.name: Frukt, bär och grönsaksöl

styles.description: Ett öl där man använder kryddor och eller örter istället för humle, för att få en tydlig, men balanserad, kryddig örtig karaktär på ölet. Kryddningen får inte dominera över ölkaraktären. Om humle används tillsammans med övriga kryddor skall inte humlen få dominera.
styles.name: Kryddöl

styles.appearance: Beror på öltypen.
styles.aroma: Öl jästa med brettar ska ha medium till hög doft av esterfruktighet, som ofta drar åt tropisk frukt. Typiskt för brettar är också doften som ofta beskrivs som stallig, hästfilt, svettigt läder osv. Denna stallighet ska märkas på medium nivå. En fenolisk karaktär är tillåten på låg nivå. DMS får inte märkas. Diacetyl, utöver vad bryggd ölstil tillåter, får inte förekomma. Uppfriskande syra på en mycket låg nivå är tillåten. I övrigt ska brettkaraktären vara i balans med ölstilen.
styles.description: Öl till vilka vildjäststammen Brettanomyces (brett brettar) tillsatts blir allt vanligare i ölvärlden. Det finns flera underklasser i huvudklass 10 där brettkaraktär är eller kan vara en del av arom- och smakbilden, men där också flera övriga bakteriestammar bidrar till karaktären. Den här underklassen, 11C, täcker alla öl med brettkaraktär som inte faller in under huvudklass 10. Öl i underklass 11C kan antingen ha primärjästs med enbart brettar eller först primärjästs med den för öltypen typiska jäststamen. Brettar har tillsatts under eller efter primärjäsningens slut. Bryggaren ska ange vilken öltyp som ligger till grund för det färdiga ölet, eftersom det är viktigt att domarna ska kunna förutse och förstå vilka aromer och smaker som bör finnas utöver de som brettjästen bidrar med. Eventuella tillsatta kryddor, frukter e.d. måste också specificeras.
styles.examples: Orval 6,2%  Abbaye Notre-Dame d'Orval - Vieille Saison  brekeriet - Saison Brett  Boulevard Brewing Co -  Brilliant  brekeriet - Cassis  brekeriet - Golden Brett  Allagash - Midnight Brett  Allagash - All Brett Citra IPA  Brodies
styles.name: Brettanomycesöl
styles.summary: Estriga med typisk stallighet från brettar i harmoni med ölstilens övriga karaktärer.
styles.texture: Brettanomycesöl är oftast väl utjästa, undantag får förekomma beroende på vald ölstil.

styles.description: I denna underklass placeras klassiska öltyper som är svårplacerade på grund av exempelvis inblandning av kryddor och frukt, samt de som ligger utanför definitionsgränserna på annat sätt. Det kan också vara rena experimentbrygder. OBS! Öl som kan placeras i en vanlig underkaterogi skall inplaceras där. Träinfluerade öl lämnas in i egen klass, se nedan. Specificera på bryggprotokollet vilken öltyp som använts som grund till det modifierade ölet samt ge information om hur det är modifierat. Udda extraktgivare som t ex melass, kandisocker, muscovadosocker, majs och ris betraktas normalt inte som modifiering. Däremot om man har använt så pass mycket av sin extraktgivare att den tydligt förändrat karaktären av den öltyp man bryggt, då bör man absolut lämna in sin öl i klass 11D - Modifierade öl.
styles.name: Modifierade öl

styles.description: Det finns en lång tradition med olika tillsatser i porter, t ex melass, lakrits och choklad. Denna klass omfattar alla dem där tillsatserna framträder märkbart, t ex honey stout, chocolate stout porter och oyster stout. Även mer experimentella porter med tillsatser av kaffe, olika bär eller 1700-tals varianter med rökmalt osv finns här. Porter Stout special kan baseras på vilken som helst av övriga porter och stout i klass 7 och 8.
styles.examples: St. Peter's Honey Porter - 4,5%, Young's Double Chocolate Stout - 5,2 %, Marston Oyster stout
styles.name: Porter Stout special

styles.appearance: Bärnstensfärgad till mörkt rödbrun.
styles.aroma: Doften skall vara tydligt rökig men ändå i balans med lagerölet. Maltdoften har ofta en lätt knäckigt rostad karaktär. Ett litet inslag av humle är okej. Ingen fruktestrighet eller diacetyl får märkas.
styles.description: Rököl skall ha en tydligt, men balanserad, rökig karaktär i smak och doft. En klassisk tysk rököl är brygd som ett lageröl.
styles.examples: Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier 5,1% IBU 30. Brauerei Spezial Lager 4,7%.
styles.flavor: Tydligt rökig smak i balans med lagerölet. Maltsmaken är ofta lätt knäckig med rostade inslag och balanseras av en medelstor beska. Högkvalitetshumle ger en liten men märkbar smak. Inga fruktestrar, diacetyl smörkola eller köldgrumling tillåtet.
styles.name: Rököl, typ Bamberg
styles.texture: Medium.

styles.appearance: Tydligt rökig smak i balans med lagerölet. Maltsmaken bör stå i relation till färgen. Mörka dubbelbockfärgade öl får ha ett visst inslag av fruktestrighet och choklad. Vinösa toner med inslag av torkad frukt är vanligt. Diacetyl får inte märkas. Högkvalitetshumle ger en liten men märkbar smak. Köldgrumling är inte tillåtet.
styles.aroma: Doften skall vara tydligt rökig men ändå i balans med lagerölet. Ett litet inslag av humle är okej. Maltdoften bör stå i relation till färgen. Mörka dubbelbockfärgade öl får ha ett visst inslag av fruktestrighet. Vinösa toner med inslag av torkad frukt är vanligt. Diacetyl får märkas.
styles.description: Rökbock skall ha en tydligt, men balanserad, rökig karaktär i smak och doft. En klassisk rökbock är brygd som ett lageröl.
styles.examples: Aecht Schlenkerla Urbock 6,5% IBU 40.
styles.flavor: Gyllengul till mörkt rödbrun.
styles.name: Rökbock
styles.texture: Stor.

styles.appearance: Varierande.
styles.aroma: I balans med basölet. Övriga karakteristika ska vara i enlighet med basölet.
styles.description: Rököl som i förhållande till basölet har en tydligt rökig karaktär men fortfarande är i balans med basölet. Med övriga rököl avses öl som inte är lageröl eller lageröl som är för starka för att lämnas in i rökbocksklassen.
styles.examples: Alaskan smoked porter OG: 1 068, 6,5%, IBU: 45.
styles.flavor: Tydligt rökig smak i balans med basölet. Övriga karakteristika ska vara i enlighet med basölet.
styles.name: Övrig rököl
styles.texture: Varierande.

styles.appearance: Bör spegla grundölet men kan vara mörkare än, särskilt om rostat trä använts.
styles.aroma: Doft av grundölet och en låg till medelstark doft av det träslag som använts. Sherrylika oxidationstoner kan förekomma, men doften skall inte vara pappig. Syrliga toner i bakgrunden kan förekomma.
styles.description: Öl vars karaktär modifierats genom lagring på fat av ek eller annat träslag, eller som lagrats med tillsats av träspån. Ange öltyp samt hur trälagringen gått till (t ex rostade ekspån, stavar av kastanjeträ eller sherryfat).
styles.examples: Bush Prestige, Petrus Aged Ale, Innis & Gunn Oak Aged Beer, Innis & Gunn Rum Cask, Innis & Gunn Island Cask, Yeti oak aged imperial stout, Avery Samael oak aged ale, Bells Oak Aged Java Stout, Cuve de Tomme Lost Abbey.
styles.flavor: Smak av grundölet kompletterat med trä. Träet kan bidra med vanilj (från vanillin i träet), karamelliserat socker, smörkola, nötter eller bränd mandel (från rostat trä), eller arom av spritdryck eller starkvin som tidigare lagrats med träet. Smakämnena från träet skall inte övertrumfa utan harmonisera med grundölets. En lätt syra kan finnas i bakgrunden.
styles.name: Trä- och fatlagrade öl
styles.texture: Bör spegla grundölet. En liten astringens från tanniner ur träet kan förekomma.

styles.description: Traditionell dricke skall innehålla gotländsk rökmalt (rökt på alved), ene och socker. Från början var dricken spontanjäst, men idag är det vanligast att bakjäst används. Ene kokas även ibland i lakvattnet innan lakning sker. Ene används också som filter under lakningen. Styrkan, färgen, rökigheten och sötman på dricken kan variera från gård till gård. De rökigaste varianterna återfinns på södra Gotland. En god dricke skall balansera rökigheten, enesmaken och sötman. Humlegivorna är mycket låga. Som riktlinje kan sägas att dom flesta dricker brukar ligga runt 6-7 vol% alkohol och att IBU ligger på knappt 1 3 av OG. Variationerna är dock stora, vilket är orsaken till att detaljerade värden på OG, FG, IBU och färg har utelämnats.
styles.name: Gotlandsdricke [Haimbryggt]

styles.appearance: Mörkt kopparfärgad till rödsvart. Skumkronan får vara liten.
styles.aroma: Ingen humlearom. Dominerande maltkaraktär. Alkoholen skall vara tydlig men ej spritig. Låg till obefintliga fruktestrar.
styles.description: En extra stark bock (oftast dubbelbock) vars karaktär koncentreras och mjuknar genom att den fryses och isen avskiljs från ölen.
styles.examples: Kulmbacher EKU 28 28% stamvörtstyrka 11 vol%. Kulmbacher Eisbock 18% stamwürsze 7,5 vol%, Niagara Eisbock 8 vol%.
styles.flavor: Maltkaraktären kan vara kraftigt söt med hög alkoholhalt. Sötman balanseras av låg humlebeska men ingen smakhumle. Fruktestrar förekommer men ej dominerande. Ingen smörkola diacetyl.
styles.name: Eisbock
styles.texture: Stor kropp. Låg kolsyrenivå.

styles.description: Här avses gamla klassiska öltyper som funnits i decennier men som har fallit lite i glömska. Dessa öl kanske bara bryggs av ett fåtal bryggerier i världen och dessutom bryggs de sällan av hembryggare.Öl inlämnade i denna kategori ska alltså inte vara experimentvarianter av en känd ölstil, inte heller nya öltyper som håller på att bli populära - dessa ska lämnas in i klass 11D Modifierade öl.
styles.name: Övriga, övriga klassiska öltyper

-K13EUAhXXSYUEXc6-Pz.name: Ale, Single stage
-K13EUAhXXSYUEXc6-Pz.notes: A simple single stage fermentation, often used by extract brewers or for classic ales.

-K0jLdC3APsYHR4round.name: Admiral
-K0jLdC3APsYHR4round.notes: Bittering hops derived from Wye Challenger. Good high-alpha bittering hops. Used for: Ales. Aroma: Primarily for bittering. Substitutes: Target, Northdown, Challenger.

-K0jLdC49ko2mTxZApyh.name: Ahtanum
-K0jLdC49ko2mTxZApyh.notes: Distinctive aromatic hops with moderate bittering power from Washington. Used for: American ales and lagers. Aroma: Distinctive floral and citrus aromas. Substitutes: Amarillo, Cascade

-K0jLdC53irf8CJdL7Hm.name: Amarillo Gold
-K0jLdC53irf8CJdL7Hm.notes: Unknown origin, but character similar to Cascade. Used for both bitterness and aroma. Used for: IPAs, Ales. Aroma: Citrus, flowery. Substitutes: Cascade, Centennial

-K0jLdC53irf8CJdL7Hn.name: Apollo
-K0jLdC53irf8CJdL7Hn.notes: Super high alpha variety from the Hopsteiner breeding program released in 2006. High alpha and low cohumulone makes it a great bittering hop. Adds a strong grapefruit/hop note if added late in boil. Substitutes: Nugget, Columbus, Tomahawk, Zeus

-K0jLdC64PlSSfYfAjlt.name: Aquila
-K0jLdC64PlSSfYfAjlt.notes: Aroma hops developed in 1988. Limited use due to high cohumolone. Used for: Aroma hops. Substitutes: Cluster. No longer commercially grown.

-K0jLdC7C85IYsl77o59.name: Atlas
-K0jLdC7C85IYsl77o59.notes: A cross between Brewers Gold and Slovenian wild hops. Primarily a bittering hop with pleasant bitterness and aroma. Used for: Bittering ales, lagers Substitutes: Brewers Gold

-K0jLdCA4trPNv3KyCXD.name: Aurora
-K0jLdCA4trPNv3KyCXD.notes: Also called Super Styrian. This is a hybrid between Northern Brewer and TG. It has a pleasant hoppy aroma similar to Styrian Goldings but lighter. Used for: Often mixed with other hops in lagers. Substitutes: Styrian Goldings

-K0jLdCBe3uIV4lDyzRb.name: Banner
-K0jLdCBe3uIV4lDyzRb.notes: Bittering hops developed in 1988. Use largely discontinued due to poor storage. Used for: U.S. style ales. Substitutes: Cluster

-K0jLdCCPZ0AmU3LjWJA.name: Bobek
-K0jLdCCPZ0AmU3LjWJA.notes: Also called Styrian Golding B - a cross between Northern Brewer and a TG seedling. Pleasant hop aroma and flavor. Used for: Moderate English ales and lagers/Pilsners Substitutes: Northern Brewer

-K0jLdCD2rjV7kZ1iWee.name: Bramling Cross
-K0jLdCD2rjV7kZ1iWee.notes: Developed in 1927 from commercial Goldings and wild hop variety. Used for: ESB, Bitters, Pale Ale. Aroma: Mild, fruity, currant aroma. Substitutes: East Kent Goldings, Progress, Whitbred

-K0jLdCETDqRYHKK330n.name: Bravo
-K0jLdCETDqRYHKK330n.notes: A second generation super high alpha hops from the Hopsteiner breeding program released in 2006. Good bittering hop. Aroma: Fruity and floral aroma. Substitutes: Columbus, Zeus, Tomahawk

-K0jLdCETDqRYHKK330o.name: Brewer's Gold
-K0jLdCETDqRYHKK330o.notes: Traditional bittering hops for English ales and heavy German lagers. Aroma: Sharp bittering hop. Substitutes: Northern Brewer, Galena, Chinook, Eroica. Example: Pete's Wicked Ale

-K0jLdCFPhObGMEPUra6.name: Bullion
-K0jLdCFPhObGMEPUra6.notes: Used in strong dark English ales, some heavy German lagers. Aroma: Strong, pungent and bitter in flavor. Blackcurrant flavor. Substitutes: Chinook, Eroica, Brewer's Gold

-K0jLdCFPhObGMEPUra7.name: Cascade
-K0jLdCFPhObGMEPUra7.notes: A hops with Northern Brewers Heritage. Used for: American ales and lagers. Aroma: Strong spicy, floral, grapefruit character. Substitutes: Centennial. Examples: Sierra Nevada Pale Ale, Anchor Liberty Ale

-K0jLdCG4S3CsVFnQIk8.name: Celeia
-K0jLdCG4S3CsVFnQIk8.notes: A dual purpose hops that is a hybrid between Savinjski Golding, Aurora and Slovenian wild hops. Similar in aroma to Saaz. Used for: Light lagers, Pilsners, Belgian ales. Substitutes: Saaz, Styrian Goldings

-K0jLdCHrFOTfCIsPMlS.name: Centennial
-K0jLdCHrFOTfCIsPMlS.notes: Used for: General purpose bittering, aroma in American ales and Wheats. Aroma: Floral, citrus aroma, spicy, clean bittering flavor. Substitutes: Galena, Eroica, Nugget, Bullion. Examples: Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale, Sierra Nevada Bigfoot

-K0jLdCHrFOTfCIsPMlT.name: Challenger
-K0jLdCHrFOTfCIsPMlT.notes: Variant of Northern Brewers heritage. Used for: Both aroma and bittering for ales and lagers. Aroma: Fruity in flavor, spicy aroma, blends well. Substitutes: N/A

-K0jLdCIZojLUVoPv8au.name: Chelan
-K0jLdCIZojLUVoPv8au.notes: High alpha variety from the Haas breeding program released in 2004. It is a variant of Galena and very similar in profile to Galena. Aroma: Pleasant citrus notes Substitutes: Galena

-K0jLdCIZojLUVoPv8av.name: Chinook
-K0jLdCIZojLUVoPv8av.notes: Strong versatile bittering hop. Used for: Ales, porters, stouts. Aroma: Heavy and spicy aroma. Substitutes: Galena, Eroica, Nugget, Bullion. Examples: Sierra Nevada Stout, Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale

-K0jLdCJA71UZd9Bglwb.name: Citra
-K0jLdCJA71UZd9Bglwb.notes: Special aroma hops released in 2007. Imparts high alpha/oil content but low cohumulone. Aroma: Adds interesting citrus and tropical fruit character to the beer. Substitutes: Unknown

-K0jLdCJA71UZd9Bglwc.name: Cluster
-K0jLdCJA71UZd9Bglwc.notes: Used for: General purpose bittering hop. Aroma: Floral, slightly spicy. Sharp aroma and sharp flavor. Substitutes: Eroica, Galena

-K0jLdCKsUFbiTo1Gcsr.name: Columbia
-K0jLdCKsUFbiTo1Gcsr.notes: Sibling of Williamette hops. Used for: All English Ales. Aroma: Close to Fuggles. Substitutes: Fuggles, Williamette

-K0jLdCLCRMlE9EP4sy_.name: Columbus (Tomahawk)
-K0jLdCLCRMlE9EP4sy_.notes: Engineered Centennial Substitute - High alpha bittering hops. Used for: Bittering, flavor, aroma - IPA, American Pale Ale, Stout, Lager. Aroma: Pungent, spicy. Strongly aromatic, but clean tasting bitterness. Substitutes: Centennial

-K0jLdCLCRMlE9EP4sya.name: Comet
-K0jLdCLCRMlE9EP4sya.notes: Very bitter hops - use sparingly with other hops. Used for: Bittering only. Substitutes: N/A

-K0jLdCMAnd_IZ0PpZgQ.name: Crystal
-K0jLdCMAnd_IZ0PpZgQ.notes: Used for: Aroma and finishing hops for Lagers. Aroma: Clean, mild, pleasant and slightly spicy. Substitutes: Hallertauer, Mount Liberty

-K0jLdCMAnd_IZ0PpZgR.name: Eroica
-K0jLdCMAnd_IZ0PpZgR.notes: Used for: General purpose bittering for ales, porters, stouts. Aroma: Clean bittering hop, very bitter. Substitutes: Galena, Northern Brewer, Chinook. Examples: Blackhook Porter, Ballard Bitter

-K0jLdCNOEYhHjKZBNtW.name: Feux Coeur Francais
-K0jLdCNOEYhHjKZBNtW.notes: Rare, high alpha hops from Australia with genetic roots in the Burgundy region of France. It was adopted to the Victoria region of Australia and introduced in 2010.

-K0jLdCOmdlPV-nO4dO9.name: First Gold
-K0jLdCOmdlPV-nO4dO9.notes: Dwarf hop with English Golding character. Used for: Ales, ESB. Aroma: Similar to other Golding varieties, spicy. Substitutes: East Kent Goldings, Crystal

-K0jLdCPykln-LhaBnpU.name: Fuggles
-K0jLdCPykln-LhaBnpU.notes: Used for: General purpose bittering/aroma for English Ales, Dark Lagers. Aroma: Mild, soft, grassy, floral aroma. Substitute: East Kent Goldings, Williamette. Examples: Samuel Smith's Pale Ale, Old Peculiar, Thomas Hardy's Ale

-K0jLdCQAfMgoZQ8ksNN.name: Galaxy
-K0jLdCQAfMgoZQ8ksNN.notes: A high alpha, dual purpose seedless hops with a unique hop aroma. It can be used either for bittering or as a late hop addition to provide a flavor of citrus and passionfruit to the finished beer. Aroma: Intense, pleasant, unique.

-K0jLdCRuFSTy_TL0ZyA.name: Galena
-K0jLdCRuFSTy_TL0ZyA.notes: Used for: General bittering hops for all beers. Aroma: Strong, clean, balanced bittering. Substitutes: Eroica, Northern Brewer, Cluster, Chinook. Examples: Catamount Porter

-K0jLdCSw5EWKKv5mK49.name: Glacier
-K0jLdCSw5EWKKv5mK49.notes: Genetic mix of at least 8 hops including Elsasser, Brewers Gold, N Brewer, Bullion, Early Green, and others..released in 2000. Used for: Aroma. Aroma: Excellent, hoppy. Substitutes: N/A

-K0jLdCTYkXMuDtL46lK.name: Goldings, B.C.
-K0jLdCTYkXMuDtL46lK.notes: Used for: Bittering and finishing British ales, bitters, porters and stouts. Aroma: Spicy, floral, rounded mild aroma. Substitutes: East Kent Goldings, Fuggles

-K0jLdCTYkXMuDtL46lL.name: Goldings, East Kent
-K0jLdCTYkXMuDtL46lL.notes: Used for: General purpose hops for bittering/finishing all British Ales. Aroma: Floral, aromatic, earthy, slightly sweet spicy flavor. Substitutes: Fuggles, BC Goldings. Examples: Bass Pale Ale, Fullers ESB, Samual Smith's Pale Ale.

-K0jLdCTYkXMuDtL46lM.name: Green Bullet
-K0jLdCTYkXMuDtL46lM.notes: Bittering hops from New Zealand developed in 1972. Used for: Australian-style ales and lagers. Aroma: Floral, raisin aroma. Substitutes: Styrian Goldings

-K0jLdCXgu1GhpRvFAsJ.name: Greenburg
-K0jLdCXgu1GhpRvFAsJ.notes: American hop variety from southern Idaho. Fruity flavor with a touch of wood flavor. Popular with microbreweries.

-K0jLdCYFoTuOmmcv_zd.name: Hallertauer
-K0jLdCYFoTuOmmcv_zd.notes: Used for: German Ales, German/US/Canadian Lagers, Wheat Beers. Aroma: Pleasant, mild spicy flavor, clean, neutral flavor. Substitutes: Crystal, Liberty, Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

-K0jLdCYFoTuOmmcv_ze.name: Hallertauer Hersbrucker
-K0jLdCYFoTuOmmcv_ze.notes: Used for: German style lagers and wheat beers. Aroma: Noble, pleasant, clean flavor. Substitutes: Mt. Hood, Liberty, Hallertauer, Mittelfrueh. Examples: Wheathook Wheaten Ale

-K0jLdCZ_Kwoz-wCwY_o.name: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh
-K0jLdCZ_Kwoz-wCwY_o.notes: Used for: Continental Lagers, German Ales/Lagers, US Lagers. Aroma: Pleasant, assertive, mild herbal aroma. Substitutes: Hallertauer, Mt. Hood, Liberty, Crystal. Examples: Sam Adams Boston Lager, Sam Adams Boston Lightship

-K0jLdCbMakJu69-rUMB.name: Hallertauer, New Zealand
-K0jLdCbMakJu69-rUMB.notes: Hallertauer variant with classic aroma and ability to retain clean taste. Bred from German Hallertauer Mittelfrueh. Used for: Australian Ales. Substitutes: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

-K0jLdCcL2E4q6vy-a7K.name: Herald
-K0jLdCcL2E4q6vy-a7K.notes: Dwarf variety bred at Wye College (mid 1990s). Used for: Bittering of ales. Aroma: Strong, acceptable. Substitutes: High alpha English bittering hops.

-K0jLdCcL2E4q6vy-a7L.name: Horizon
-K0jLdCcL2E4q6vy-a7L.notes: Good dual purpose hops derived from Nugget hops in Oregon (1970). Used for: All purpose Ales, Lagers. Aroma: Pleasant, hoppy. Substitutes: Magnum or other high alpha hops

-K0jLdCdFvX3ARpbtE1u.name: Liberty
-K0jLdCdFvX3ARpbtE1u.notes: Used for: German style lagers. Aroma: Fine, mild, slightly spicy flavor. Substitutes: Hallertau, Mt Hood, Crystal. Examples: Pete's Wicked Lager

-K0jLdCep_97KxcmMlXs.name: Lublin
-K0jLdCep_97KxcmMlXs.notes: Version of Saaz grown in Poland - also called "Lubelski". Used for: Bohemian lagers and Pilsners. Aroma: Noble, mild flavor similar to Saaz. Substitutes: Saaz, Tettnanger

-K0jLdCfL-kPtySfjS8N.name: Magnum
-K0jLdCfL-kPtySfjS8N.notes: German Hallertauer hybrid, widely used in Germany. Used for: German ales and lagers. Aroma: Good aroma and stable spicy flavor. Substitutes: N/A

-K0jLdCgfwb86jcBEJCX.name: Marynka
-K0jLdCgfwb86jcBEJCX.notes: Bittering hops with high aroma. Primarily for use in Pilsner, lagers, ales or wheats. Comparable to English Goldings or Chinook. Used for: Lager, ales. Substitutes: Chinook, English Golding

-K0jLdCh79XkwZqkElpZ.name: Millenium
-K0jLdCh79XkwZqkElpZ.notes: Originally developed as part of the Haas breeding program in the US, Millenium entered production in 2000. It is a very high alpha hops used for bittering. Aroma: Mild, herbal. Substitutes: Columbus, Tomahawk, Zeus and Nugget

-K0jLdCh79XkwZqkElp_.name: Motueka
-K0jLdCh79XkwZqkElp_.notes: Flexible hop developed from Saaz. Has notable character and aroma, balanced bitterness, and unique flavor. Used for: Lagers, Belgian Ales and Bohemian Pilsner. Substitutes: Saaz

-K0jLdCi_kkDa2FNGHuJ.name: Mt. Hood
-K0jLdCi_kkDa2FNGHuJ.notes: Used for: European Lagers, finishing. Aroma: Mild with a clean aroma, neutral flavor. Somewhat pungent. Substitutes: Hallertauer, Liberty, Crystal

-K0jLdCi_kkDa2FNGHuK.name: Nelson Sauvin
-K0jLdCi_kkDa2FNGHuK.notes: Triploid variety bred from "Smoothcone" released in 2000. Oil profile said to taste like "fresh crushed gooseberries" similar to Sauvignon Blanc, giving it its name. Very fruity, citrusy - use in moderation. Used for: Pale ale, Super Premiums. Substitutes: None

-K0jLdCj5rM6qq4Vf50v.name: Newport
-K0jLdCj5rM6qq4Vf50v.notes: High alpha hops released in 2002 as a potential replacement for Galena. Note that these hops have a large alpha range of 9.8%-17% so check the package! Fairly pungent. Used for: Primarily used for bittering in ales, stouts, barley wine. Substitutes: Galena

-K0jLdCj5rM6qq4Vf50w.name: Northdown
-K0jLdCj5rM6qq4Vf50w.notes: Variation of Northern Brewers hops grown in England. Used for: Bittering in English ales. Aroma: Good bittering, flavor and aroma. Substitutes: Northern Brewer

-K0jLdCk2TAcCkJIxwKy.name: Northern Brewer
-K0jLdCk2TAcCkJIxwKy.notes: Also called Hallertauer Northern Brewers. Used for: Bittering and finishing both ales and lagers of all kinds. Aroma: Fine, dry, clean bittering hop. Unique flavor. Substitutes: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh, Hallertauer. Examples: Anchor Steam, Old Peculiar

-K0jLdCk2TAcCkJIxwKz.name: Nugget
-K0jLdCk2TAcCkJIxwKz.notes: Used for: Bittering hops for ales. Aroma: Strong bittering, heavy, herbal aroma, spicy. Substitutes: Chinook. Examples: Sierra Nevada Porter

-K0jLdClsHQNjm6IqoUs.name: Olympic
-K0jLdClsHQNjm6IqoUs.notes: Olympic is a high alpha hops released by Washington Agricultural Expt Station in 1983. Heritage is from Brewers Gold and Fuggles. Aroma: Spicy, citrus aroma. Substitutes: Brewers Gold

-K0jLdCmsY1V8Kse8KU4.name: Opal
-K0jLdCmsY1V8Kse8KU4.notes: New variety from the hop research center in Hull. Used for: Aroma hops in continental styles. Aroma: High aroma hops with hints of spice and subtle citrus. Substitutes: Unknown

-K0jLdCmsY1V8Kse8KU5.name: Orion
-K0jLdCmsY1V8Kse8KU5.notes: Cross between Perle and an experimental variety. Used for: Bittering and aroma. Aroma: Pleasant, hoppy. Substitutes: Perle

-K0jLdCndFuH1wLW3mg_.name: Pacific Gem
-K0jLdCndFuH1wLW3mg_.notes: High alpha smoothcone cross developed at DSIR in 1987. Used for: Bittering - produces a cask-oak woody flavor. Aroma: Pleasant - some blackberry aroma. Substitutes: Bullion

-K0jLdCpTMjFDidI24vM.name: Pacific Jade
-K0jLdCpTMjFDidI24vM.notes: High alpha bittering hops that delivers a bold herbal infusion of fresh citrus with some black pepper flavor. Citrus aroma and flavor tempers ales and may be used as a finishing hops. Used for: Ales, lagers Substitutes: N/A

-K0jLdCqtAbubuTZk1J9.name: Pacifica
-K0jLdCqtAbubuTZk1J9.notes: Aroma hop developed from Hallertauer Mittelfrueh in New Zealand (1994). Blend of old and new world taste including Orange marmalade and citrus aroma notes when used in late addition. Soft finish if used in bittering. Substitutes: Chinook, Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

-K0jLdCr-YX0MIUlboah.name: Palisade
-K0jLdCr-YX0MIUlboah.notes: Also called YCR-4, Palisade is an aroma variety bread by Yakima Chief Ranches. It has both aromatic and moderate bittering properties. Substitutes: Willamette

-K0jLdCr-YX0MIUlboai.name: Perle
-K0jLdCr-YX0MIUlboai.notes: Used for: General purpose bittering for US and German ales, lagers. Aroma: Slightly spicy, pleasant aroma, minty. Substitutes: Chinook, Galena, Northern Brewer. Examples: Sierra Nevada Pale Ale, Pale Bock

-K0jLdCsoaJIeM1XE9gQ.name: Phoenix
-K0jLdCsoaJIeM1XE9gQ.notes: Seedling derived from Wye Yoeman. Used for: Ales. Aroma: Similar to Wye Challenger hops. Substitutes: Challenger, East Kent Golding, Northdown

-K0jLdCtzz-j0RA7GP_-.name: Pilgrim
-K0jLdCtzz-j0RA7GP_-.notes: New variety from Wye College in 2001. High Selinene content. Used for: Bittering. Substitutes: N/A

-K0jLdCu31aI7dXbrQGF.name: Pilot
-K0jLdCu31aI7dXbrQGF.notes: A very new hops introduced in 2002 by Charles Faram & Co Ltd. Mild herbal flavor with lemon hints and fresh mowed grass flavor. Used for: Primarily for bittering in APAs. Rare.

-K0jLdCvmKIyFyV1QquH.name: Pioneer
-K0jLdCvmKIyFyV1QquH.notes: Bred from Wye Omega at Wye College in the UK. Used for: ESB, English Ales. Aroma: Mild English hop aroma. Substitutes: East Kent Goldings

-K0jLdCxGhNkDDj6g8-H.name: Premiant
-K0jLdCxGhNkDDj6g8-H.notes: A cross between Czech aroma and bittering varieties. Dual purpose though its aroma is not as strong as some other Czech hops. Use in beers where a moderate hoppy aroma is needed. Used for: Moderate ales, lagers Substitutes: Saaz

-K0jLdCzNB7rOvHaZm2l.name: Pride of Ringwood
-K0jLdCzNB7rOvHaZm2l.notes: Used for: General purpose bittering hops for Australian beers. Aroma: Moderate citric aroma, clean bittering flavor. Substitutes: Cluster, Galena

-K0jLdD-j5IsDakrPVhD.name: Progress
-K0jLdD-j5IsDakrPVhD.notes: Used for: Bittering and aroma in English Ales. Aroma: Similar to Fuggles, aromatic, slightly sweet. Substitutes: Fuggles

-K0jLdD0U1dkMdJ-dpjw.name: Riwaka
-K0jLdD0U1dkMdJ-dpjw.notes: Formerly called B-Saaz, this was developed from old line Saazer hops in New Zealand. Used for: New world pale ale, regional pilsners. Aroma: Strong, hoppy. Some grapefruit and citrus character.

-K0jLdD12Z6rEpVR3sRe.name: Saaz
-K0jLdD12Z6rEpVR3sRe.notes: Used for: Pilsners and Bohemian style lagers. Aroma: Delicate, mild, clean, somewhat floral -- Noble hops. Substitutes: Tettnanger, Lublin. Examples: Pulsner Urquell

-K0jLdD12Z6rEpVR3sRf.name: Santiam
-K0jLdD12Z6rEpVR3sRf.notes: Triploid aroma selection derived from Tettnang and Hallertauer (1997). Used for: Lager, U.S. Pale Ale, Pilsner. Substitutes: German Tettnang, Spalt, Spalt Select

-K0jLdD3NKN5RdY91UBx.name: Saphir
-K0jLdD3NKN5RdY91UBx.notes: A new noble breed as an alternative to Hallertau Mittelfrueh in an attempt to make it more disease resistant and commercially viable. Similar in character to Hallertau varieties. Used for: Pilsners, lagers, Belgian whites. Substitutes: Hallertau Mittelfrueh

-K0jLdD4XLL-q39oSFke.name: Satus
-K0jLdD4XLL-q39oSFke.notes: High alpha bittering hops from Yakima that is similar to Galena. Of recent origin. Substitutes: Galena

-K0jLdD52BkUNMVLVL0w.name: Select Spalt
-K0jLdD52BkUNMVLVL0w.notes: Bred from Hallertauer Mittelfrueh and Spalt in Germany. Spalt character. Used for: Lager, Pilsner, Noble aroma hop substitute. Aroma: Very fine, spalt aroma. Substitutes: Spalter, Saaz, Tettnang

-K0jLdD65CfZkojlqUIq.name: Simcoe
-K0jLdD65CfZkojlqUIq.notes: High alpha bittering hops with good aroma characteristics. Used for: IPAs. Aroma: Citrus and pine-like aroma. Substitutes: N/A

-K0jLdD8slJE8DW4TX1I.name: Sladek
-K0jLdD8slJE8DW4TX1I.notes: Hybrid variety of Saaz origin with noble hoppy taste and aroma. Generally recommended for middle-hopping about 20 min before end of boil. Not a replacement for Saaz, but complimentary in Lagers. Used for: Lager Substitutes: Saaz

-K0jLdD8slJE8DW4TX1J.name: Sorachi Ace
-K0jLdD8slJE8DW4TX1J.notes: Developed by Sapporo Breweries and used in their beers - has a Brewer's gold and Saaz heritage. Reported to be lemony in flavor and aroma. Used for: Saison, IPA or other beer where lemon/citrus is desirable. Substitutes: Admiral, Cascade

-K0jLdD9tstKdxI2MveF.name: Southern Cross
-K0jLdD9tstKdxI2MveF.notes: Dual purpose with "European" flavor - from DSIR in 1994. Used for: European flavor bittering/aroma. Aroma: Spicy, lemony, slight pine and wood flavors. Substitutes: N/A

-K0jLdDAs3vAKaOMsK-L.name: Spalter
-K0jLdDAs3vAKaOMsK-L.notes: Used for: Traditional German bittering and aroma hops, Altbiers, Lagers. Aroma: Mild, pleasant, slight spice. Substitutes: Saaz, Tettnang. Examples: Dusseldorf Altbiers

-K0jLdDAs3vAKaOMsK-M.name: Sterling
-K0jLdDAs3vAKaOMsK-M.notes: Flavor is a cross between Saaz and Mt Hood. Used for: Lagers, Ales, Pilsners. Aroma: Herbal, spicy, some floral and citrus hints. Substitutes: Saaz, Polish Lublin

-K0jLdDBPuWnxxjiWEHe.name: Sticklebract
-K0jLdDBPuWnxxjiWEHe.notes: High alpha hops from DSIR research first released in 1972. Some of the same qualities as Northern Brewer. Used for: Dual purpose. Aroma: Pine-like with a hint of citrus. Substitutes: Northern Brewer

-K0jLdDBPuWnxxjiWEHf.name: Strisslespalt
-K0jLdDBPuWnxxjiWEHf.notes: Aroma hops used widely in the Alsace area of France. Used for: Pilsner, lager, wheat. Aroma: Medium intensity, pleasant, hoppy. Substitutes: Mt Hood, Crystal, Hallertauer Hersbruck

-K0jLdDCzk4dB6twFctT.name: Styrian Goldings
-K0jLdDCzk4dB6twFctT.notes: A seedless version of Fuggles grown in Slovenia. Used for: Bittering, finishing for a wide variety of European Beers. Popular in Europe and the United Kingdom. Aroma: Mild, soft, grassy, floral aroma. Similar to Fuggles. Substitutes: Fuggles, Williamette

-K0jLdDCzk4dB6twFctU.name: Summit
-K0jLdDCzk4dB6twFctU.notes: High alpha variety bred by American Dwarf Hop Assoc. Can be grown commercially on a low trellis. Aroma: Strong citrus, grapefruit notes. Substitutes: Warrior, Millenium, Columbus, Tomahawk, Zeus

-K0jLdDDNJ-vj_VJquvG.name: Sun
-K0jLdDDNJ-vj_VJquvG.notes: A very high alpha bittering hops from Yakima Valley, Washington. Used for: Bittering (intense). Aroma: Pleasant, hoppy. Substitutes: Other very high alpha US hops

-K0jLdDDNJ-vj_VJquvH.name: Super Alpha
-K0jLdDDNJ-vj_VJquvH.notes: High alpha hops released in 1976 by DSIR. European in character - clean crisp flavor and resin aroma. Used for: European Styles, General purpose bittering. Aroma: Pleasant, resin like aroma. Substitutes: N/A

-K0jLdDEVT-hMNIO2j5D.name: Super Galena
-K0jLdDEVT-hMNIO2j5D.notes: Super high alpha hops from Hopsteiner breeding program released in 2006. High alpha and beta content - comparable to Galena in bitterness and aroma profile. Used for: Primarily for bitterness. Substitutes: Galena

-K0jLdDF7K5hFV438al-.name: Super Pride
-K0jLdDF7K5hFV438al-.notes: A high alpha variation of the Pride of Ringwood hop variety. Features mild aromas, higher alpha content and low cohumulone levels. Used for: Primarily for bittering. Substitutes: Pride of Ringwood

-K0jLdDGJGo6IrwXHJYk.name: Target
-K0jLdDGJGo6IrwXHJYk.notes: Used for: English ales and lagers. Aroma: Robust aroma and flavor. Substitutes: East Kent Goldings

-K0jLdDGJGo6IrwXHJYl.name: Tettnang
-K0jLdDGJGo6IrwXHJYl.notes: Used for: German ales, lagers and wheat beer. Aroma: Noble, mild, fine, slightly spicy. Substitutes: Saaz, Spalt. Examples: Sam Adams Octoberfest, Anderson Valley ESB

-K0jLdDHsZ80AZvVsUiq.name: Tillicum
-K0jLdDHsZ80AZvVsUiq.notes: High alpha and high beta hops developed though Haas breeding program and released in 1995. Daughter variety of Galena and related to Chelan - so similar to both. Substitutes: Galena, Chelan

-K0jLdDInCdsu0xOVSUs.name: Tomahawk
-K0jLdDInCdsu0xOVSUs.notes: Part of the Columbus/Tomahak/Zeus (CTZ) group of super high alpha hops. Together these make up 1/4 of US hop acreage. Used for: High alpha hops used primarily for commercial bittering. Substitutes: Tomahawk, Zeus, Nugget, Galena, Chinook

-K0jLdDJQVFOvJlBEAzn.name: Topaz
-K0jLdDJQVFOvJlBEAzn.notes: Very high alpha hop variety from Australia. Used for commercial production primarily for its high alpha acid content and high bitterness.

-K0jLdDKiPhiDrPFnwey.name: Tradition
-K0jLdDKiPhiDrPFnwey.notes: Close descendant of Hallertauer Mittelfrueh bred for high yield. Used for: Lager, Pilsner, Bock, some Weizens. Aroma: Fine - similar to Hallertauer Mittelfrueh. Substitutes: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh, Liberty, Ultra

-K0jLdDKiPhiDrPFnwez.name: Ultra
-K0jLdDKiPhiDrPFnwez.notes: Triploid seedling of the German Hallertauer Variety. Used for: Lager, Pilsner, wheat, finishing hops in ales. Aroma: Good to outstanding - some Saaz like qualities. Substitutes: Liberty, Hallertauer, Tradition, Saaz

-K0jLdDLVVdvboQNOLt8.name: Vanguard
-K0jLdDLVVdvboQNOLt8.notes: Diploid seedling made in 1982, released in 1997. Hallertau Mitterfrueh parentage. Used for: European lagers, ales. Aroma: Strong aromatic notes. Substitutes: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

-K0jLdDM5DdbpZz0keH7.name: Victoria
-K0jLdDM5DdbpZz0keH7.notes: Hi alpha hops grown in Victoria, Australia. It was created in 1976 and entered commercial production in the 1990s. Used for: Primarily for bittering due to high alpha content.

-K0jLdDM5DdbpZz0keH8.name: Warrior
-K0jLdDM5DdbpZz0keH8.notes: High alpha hops from Yakima Chief Ranches. Also called YCR-5. Mild aroma and low cohumulone content - primarily for bittering. Used for: Ales, stouts. Aroma: Neutral, clean, mild. Substitutes: Nugget, Columbus, Magnum

-K0jLdDNhnMw7WAHT-wt.name: Whitbread Golding Variety (WGV)
-K0jLdDNhnMw7WAHT-wt.notes: Derived in England in 1911 from Bates Brewer. Some Golding characteristics, but lacking the full Goldings aroma. Used for: Ales. Aroma: Pleasant, hoppy, slightly intense. Substitutes: East Kent Goldings, Progress

-K0jLdDOE6zdWMggT9OJ.name: Willamette
-K0jLdDOE6zdWMggT9OJ.notes: Used for: Finishing American and British Ales. Aroma: Mild, grassy, floral, slightly spicy. Substitutes: Fuggles, East Kent Goldings. Examples: Sierra Nevada Porter, Ballard Bitter

-K0jLdDOE6zdWMggT9OK.name: Zeus
-K0jLdDOE6zdWMggT9OK.notes: Super high alpha bittering hops developed in the Yakima Valley, WA. Used for: Bittering, intense aroma. Aroma: Aromatic, pleasant. Substitutes: Other high alpha hops

-K0jLd6yZ1jBk-N3oQ01.name: Amber Dry Extract
-K0jLd6yZ1jBk-N3oQ01.notes: Amber colored dry malt extract, for general purpose use. Use in any medium to dark colored beer. Examples: Ales, Marzens, Amber Ale, India Pale Ale

-K0jLd6zFJk4CeQZ17Bh.name: Amber Liquid Extract
-K0jLd6zFJk4CeQZ17Bh.notes: Unhopped amber color liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any Ale. Examples: Amber ale, India Pale Ale, Munich style, Marzen, Bock

-K0jLd7-IS0DK0ggEqyA.name: Barley Hulls
-K0jLd7-IS0DK0ggEqyA.notes: Hulls are introduced to improve the speed of lautering when making high gravity or high adjunct beers. Hulls are neutral in flavor, body and color, and are inert Good for wheat beers, Wits, and others that have high protein mashes.

-K0jLd70FQJaDCuWUiOA.name: Barley, Torrefied
-K0jLd70FQJaDCuWUiOA.notes: Raw barley that has been "popped" open to open kernels Used in place of raw barley for faster conversion and higher yields. High in haze producing protein

-K0jLd71m2cTUQF9Rq6h.name: Black (Patent) Malt
-K0jLd71m2cTUQF9Rq6h.notes: Dark color and dry roasted flavor characteristic of Stouts and Porters Use for: Coloring in small amounts, or flavoring of Stouts and Porters in larger amounts.

-K0jLd72MAXCk1ErNb7Q.name: Black Barley (Stout)
-K0jLd72MAXCk1ErNb7Q.notes: Unmalted barley roasted at high temperature to create a dry, coffee like flavor. Imparts a sharp acrid flavor characteristic of dry stouts. Gives "dryness" to a stout or porter -- much more so than regular Roasted Barley

-K0jLd73iaLtIHYhES1I.name: Brown Sugar, Dark
-K0jLd73iaLtIHYhES1I.notes: Imparts a rich sweet flavor. Used in Scottish ales, holiday ales and some old ales.

-K0jLd747h_T-W3edn8H.name: Brown Sugar, Light
-K0jLd747h_T-W3edn8H.notes: Imparts a rich sweet flavor. Used in Scottish ales, holiday ales and some old ales.

-K0jLd78n-LHY5q2sO4y.name: Candi Sugar, Amber
-K0jLd78n-LHY5q2sO4y.notes: Crystalized Candi Sugar (Sucrose) used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales.  Adds head retention and sweet aroma to beer.  Darker variants also add color.

-K0jLd7D_NfMVZvWlpQU.name: Candi Sugar, Clear
-K0jLd7D_NfMVZvWlpQU.notes: Crystalized Candi Sugar (Sucrose) used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales.  Adds head retention and sweet aroma to beer.  Darker variants also add color.

-K0jLd7Gb1Ptf5RQQDq0.name: Candi Sugar, Dark
-K0jLd7Gb1Ptf5RQQDq0.notes: Crystalized Candi Sugar (Sucrose) used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales.  Adds head retention and sweet aroma to beer.  Darker variants also add color.

-K0jLd7HI8Ds60W7l1P7.name: Cane (Beet) Sugar
-K0jLd7HI8Ds60W7l1P7.notes: Common household baking sugar. Lightens flavor and body of beer. Can contribute a cider-like flavor to the beer if not cold-fermented or used in large quantities.

-K0jLd7I1EBp8MQzzg35.name: Cara-Pils/Dextrine
-K0jLd7I1EBp8MQzzg35.notes: Significantly increases foam/head retention and body of the beer. Also sold under the names "Dextrine" and "Cara-Foam"

-K0jLd7KzRzScfjNfLX7.name: Caraamber
-K0jLd7KzRzScfjNfLX7.notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

-K0jLd7L_c0GfCZzfYk9.name: Caraaroma
-K0jLd7L_c0GfCZzfYk9.notes: Very dark crystal malt - similar to a crystal 120 or Caramunich 120 malt.  Adds strong caramel flavor, red color, and malty aroma.

-K0jLd7M71wB-ezuIffH.name: Carafa I
-K0jLd7M71wB-ezuIffH.notes: Used to intensify aroma and color in dark, Munich beers and stouts.

-K0jLd7Pe48bqvKwV4va.name: Carafa II
-K0jLd7Pe48bqvKwV4va.notes: Used to intensify aroma and color in dark, Munich beers and stouts.

-K0jLd7QAejxgCGd7_z0.name: Carafa III
-K0jLd7QAejxgCGd7_z0.notes: Dark color and aroma - used in some German beers

-K0jLd7ShlyjwLu2U3Ep.name: Carafoam
-K0jLd7ShlyjwLu2U3Ep.notes: Significantly increases foam/head retention and body of the beer. Also sold under the names "Dextrine" and "Cara-Pils (TM)"

-K0jLd7TEKr3mP-9GOI7.name: Caramel Wheat Malt
-K0jLd7TEKr3mP-9GOI7.notes: Caramel wheat malt - emphasizes wheat malt aroma and adds color to the beer.  Popular for Dunkelweizens.  Also known as Carawheat -- which is a registered trademark of Wyermann Malting.

-K0jLd7VgHRNrXEFLSJO.name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 10L
-K0jLd7VgHRNrXEFLSJO.notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

-K0jLd7X5ouu4XSgIYwC.name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 20L
-K0jLd7X5ouu4XSgIYwC.notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

-K0jLd7ZPAq4eNZWAjtl.name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 30L
-K0jLd7ZPAq4eNZWAjtl.notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

-K0jLd7cjNzm_k2mwAHp.name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 40L
-K0jLd7cjNzm_k2mwAHp.notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

-K0jLd7gKr5INzUA-Usz.name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 60L
-K0jLd7gKr5INzUA-Usz.notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

-K0jLd7i_DUHY32txD4d.name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 80L
-K0jLd7i_DUHY32txD4d.notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

-K0jLd7k7rdkA0F_8ooc.name: Caramel/Crystal Malt -120L
-K0jLd7k7rdkA0F_8ooc.notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.  Very Dark

-K0jLd7l1lUHQN8VywGj.name: Caramunich Malt
-K0jLd7l1lUHQN8VywGj.notes: Caramel, copper colored malt.  Used in Belgian ales and German bocks.

-K0jLd7mEGZhsi6qd2mr.name: Carared
-K0jLd7mEGZhsi6qd2mr.notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

-K0jLd7mEGZhsi6qd2ms.name: Caravienne Malt
-K0jLd7mEGZhsi6qd2ms.notes: Light Belgian crystal malt.  Used in light Trappist and Abbey style Belgian ales.

-K0jLd7nTahuhBPjNiEg.name: Chocolate Malt
-K0jLd7nTahuhBPjNiEg.notes: Dark malt that gives a rich red or brown color and nutty flavor. Use for: Brown ales, porters, some stouts Maintains some malty flavor, not as dark as roasted malt.

-K0jLd7op1LCfF0N1bqw.name: Chocolate Malt
-K0jLd7op1LCfF0N1bqw.notes: Dark malt that gives a rich red or brown color and nutty flavor. Use for: Brown ales, porters, some stouts Maintains some malty flavor, not as dark as roasted malt.

-K0jLd7pimL1XRw-AJc7.name: Chocolate Rye Malt
-K0jLd7pimL1XRw-AJc7.notes: Primarily used for color and aroma in top-fermented specialty beers.

-K0jLd7sh0XV9fgWfLS7.name: Chocolate Wheat Malt
-K0jLd7sh0XV9fgWfLS7.notes: Intensifies aroma and color in top-fermented beers such as dark wheat beers.

-K0jLd7xljWB9Y4dV9Xi.name: Corn Sugar (Dextrose)
-K0jLd7xljWB9Y4dV9Xi.notes: Widely used for bottling at rate of approx 2/3 cup per 5 gallons of beer

-K0jLd7zRhXyJVoj6XEE.name: Corn Syrup
-K0jLd7zRhXyJVoj6XEE.notes: Syrup derived from corn with many of the same properties as corn sugar.  May be used to enhance gravity without adding much body or flavor.  Limit percentage in batch to avoid wine/cider flavors.

-K0jLd8-tZY5pGAIP0bF.name: Dark Dry Extract
-K0jLd8-tZY5pGAIP0bF.notes: Dark dry extract for general purpose use. Use as base or to increase gravity of any dark ale or lager.

-K0jLd80DcB0Y-ODzNtU.name: Dark Liquid Extract
-K0jLd80DcB0Y-ODzNtU.notes: Unhopped dark liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any dark beer. Examples: Porter, Brown ale, Bock, Oktoberfest, Stouts

-K0jLd812S3LjmvNCs8H.name: Dememera Sugar
-K0jLd812S3LjmvNCs8H.notes: Dark, unrefined brown sugar that contains molasses and other dark impurities.  Great for brown ales and porters.  Adds slight sweetness and smooth character.

-K0jLd83xqpm1M3jVLnY.name: Extra Light Dry Extract
-K0jLd83xqpm1M3jVLnY.notes: Very light color dry malt extract for general purpose use. Use as base or to increase gravity of any ale or lager.

-K0jLd843P7R8HM0w4hO.name: Grits
-K0jLd843P7R8HM0w4hO.notes: Imparts a corn or grain taste.  Mash required. Used to increase gravity of American lagers.

-K0jLd85qpSlw2KqUiBt.name: Honey
-K0jLd85qpSlw2KqUiBt.notes: Can be used to lighten flavor and body when substituted for malt. Generally limit to 30% when used as an adjunct. Pasturize and add to primary during fermentation. Use up to 100% for meads.

-K0jLd867OLc230vn0-s.name: Invert Sugar
-K0jLd867OLc230vn0-s.notes: Used to increase starting gravity and also as an adjunct for some Belgian and English ales.

-K0jLd87j-U3yuQL4JKt.name: Light Dry Extract
-K0jLd87j-U3yuQL4JKt.notes: Pale dry malt extract for general purpose use. Use as base or to increase gravity of any full bodied ale or lager.

-K0jLd889dmVELK2IDxe.name: Lyle's Golden Syrup
-K0jLd889dmVELK2IDxe.notes: Liquid Invert Sugar.  Used to increase alcohol and lighten the beer without alterning flavor.  Used in Belgian ales and some English ales.

-K0jLd8B1dkLlDCfmvpO.name: Maple Syrup
-K0jLd8B1dkLlDCfmvpO.notes: If added during the boil it will add a dry, woodsy flavor. If added at bottling, the smooth maple flavor comes through.  Used for maple ales, porters, browns.

-K0jLd8DJ5nTkC3V8xp8.name: Milk Sugar (Lactose)
-K0jLd8DJ5nTkC3V8xp8.notes: Not fully fermentable, so it adds lasting sweetness. Lactose can be added to lend  sweetness to Sweet Stouts and Porters.

-K0jLd8Fq3-A7bhVkN0r.name: Molasses
-K0jLd8Fq3-A7bhVkN0r.notes: Imparts a strong, sweet flavor.  Used primarily in stouts and porters.

-K0jLd8GYIbozuge8f1_.name: Pale Liquid Extract
-K0jLd8GYIbozuge8f1_.notes: Unhopped pale liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any ale or lager.

-K0jLd8HFZMBaiDqXs2O.name: Peat Smoked Malt
-K0jLd8HFZMBaiDqXs2O.notes: Robust smoky malt that provides a smoky flavor.  Used in scottish ales and wee heavy ales.

-K0jLd8HFZMBaiDqXs2P.name: Pilsner Liquid Extract
-K0jLd8HFZMBaiDqXs2P.notes: Unhopped pale liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any ale or lager.

-K0jLd8I_sNyld3-NcnV.name: Rice Extract Syrup
-K0jLd8I_sNyld3-NcnV.notes: Used like other rice adjuncts in American and Japenes lagers to provide a dry, clean taste and light body.  Adds gravity without changing body or flavor substantially.  Use in place of corn sugar in small quantities.

-K0jLd8JXFNDXmn4wUoG.name: Rice Hulls
-K0jLd8JXFNDXmn4wUoG.notes: Hulls are introduced to improve the speed of lautering when making high gravity or high adjunct beers. Hulls are neutral in flavor, body and color, and are inert Good for wheat beers, Wits, and others that have high protein mashes.

-K0jLd8JXFNDXmn4wUoH.name: Roasted Barley
-K0jLd8JXFNDXmn4wUoH.notes: Roasted at high temperature to create a burnt, grainy, coffee like flavor. Imparts a red to deep brown color to beer, and very strong roasted flavor. Use 2-4% in Brown ales to add a nutty flavor, or 3-10% in Porters and Stouts for coffee flavor.

-K0jLd8KwBfK2NN2JZd7.name: Rye Malt
-K0jLd8KwBfK2NN2JZd7.notes: Adds a dry, crisp character to the beer.   Yields a deep red color, and a distinctive rye flavor Must limit to 10-15% fo the mash as it tends to produce "stuck" mashes.

-K0jLd8LCNWFoEqBLZiu.name: Rye, Flaked
-K0jLd8LCNWFoEqBLZiu.notes: Imparts a dry, crisp rye flavor to rye beers.  Can be easier to mash than raw rye.

-K0jLd8LCNWFoEqBLZiv.name: Smoked Malt
-K0jLd8LCNWFoEqBLZiv.notes: Malt that has been smoked over an open fire. Creates a distinctive "smoked" flavor and aroma. Used primarily for German Rauchbier but can also be added to Brown Ales and Porters.

-K0jLd8M_SQJhI52HzOd.name: Special B Malt
-K0jLd8M_SQJhI52HzOd.notes: Extreme caramel aroma and flavored malt.  Used in dark Belgian Abbey and Trappist ales.  Unique flavor and aroma.

-K0jLd8OS_-RP6CLAux7.name: Sugar, Table (Sucrose)
-K0jLd8OS_-RP6CLAux7.notes: White table sugar, or sucrose primarily is used to increase alcohol. Using too much will add a cider flavor to beer.

-K0jLd8PBP2WFoJ5VAOA.name: Treacle
-K0jLd8PBP2WFoJ5VAOA.notes: UK mixture of molasses, invert sugar and golden (corn) syrup.  Imparts an intense sweet flavor and dark color.  Used in dark English ales.  Also called "Black Treacle" or the brand name "Lyle's Black Treacle Syrup."

-K0jLd8Qhs6CFBlr5rbm.name: Turbinado
-K0jLd8Qhs6CFBlr5rbm.notes: Light, raw brown sugar.  May be used in British pale ales or high gravity Belgian ales.  Limit percentage used to avoid undesirable flavors.  Similar to Demerara sugar.

-K0jLd8RLud3Z4JxdY6O.name: Wheat Dry Extract
-K0jLd8RLud3Z4JxdY6O.notes: Wheat based dry extract for use in all wheat beers. Use as base or to increase gravity of any wheat beer. Examples: Weizen, weiss, wheat ales and lagers

-K0jLd8X4fy1ViBshyuU.name: Wheat Liquid Extract
-K0jLd8X4fy1ViBshyuU.notes: Unhopped Wheat liquid malt extract. Contains approx 60% Wheat, 40% Barley. Use for Bavarian wheats, weizens, weiss and dunkel weizen styles.

-K0jLd8ZMtZNAWoq63HH.name: Munich Malt
-K0jLd8ZMtZNAWoq63HH.notes: Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a reddish amber color to the beer. Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention. Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers

-K0jLd8_5m2mwcAD5BfI.name: Munich Malt - 10L
-K0jLd8_5m2mwcAD5BfI.notes: Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a slight orange color to the beer. Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention. Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers

-K0jLd8aukxWx7eNEwqb.name: Munich Malt - 20L
-K0jLd8aukxWx7eNEwqb.notes: Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a orange to deep orange color to the beer. Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention. Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers

-K0jLd8cGt7XHPTxSLd9.name: Barley, Flaked
-K0jLd8cGt7XHPTxSLd9.notes: Adds significant body to Porters and Stouts.  High haze producing protein prevents use in light beers.

-K0jLd8dHAKwvWM9zclt.name: Barley, Raw
-K0jLd8dHAKwvWM9zclt.notes: Raw, unmalted barley can be used to add body to your beer.  Use in homebrew requires very fine milling combined with a decoction or multi-stage mash.  Performs best when used in small quantities with well modified grains.

-K0jLd8ejTX7hxpkfPWd.name: Oats, Flaked
-K0jLd8ejTX7hxpkfPWd.notes: Adds body, mouth feel and head retention to the beer Used in oatmeal stouts and porters Adds substantial protein haze to light beers Protein rest recommended unless flakes are pregelatinized

-K0jLd8f5eQvaSqL70Sk.name: Oats, Malted
-K0jLd8f5eQvaSqL70Sk.notes: Malted oats.  Adds body, mouth feel and head retention to the beer  Creates chill haze in lighter beers, so is primarily used in dark ones.

-K0jLd8g21XkKEG-IBWA.name: Amber Malt
-K0jLd8g21XkKEG-IBWA.notes: Roasted specialty malt used in some English browns, milds and old ales to add color and a biscuit taste.  Intense flavor - so limit use. Low diastatic power so must be mashed with well modified malts.

-K0jLd8heYMjAz4WKCF0.name: Biscuit Malt
-K0jLd8heYMjAz4WKCF0.notes: Use for English ales, brown ales and porters. Adds a biscuit like flavor and aroma. Can be used as a substitute for toasted malt.

-K0jLd8iH1XjSM__J2jg.name: Brumalt
-K0jLd8iH1XjSM__J2jg.notes: Dark German malt developed to add malt flavor of Alt, Marzen and Oktoberfest beers. Helps create authentic maltiness without having to do a decoction mash.  Rarely available for homebrewers.

-K0jLd8maEKtoD6KoEuP.name: Honey Malt
-K0jLd8maEKtoD6KoEuP.notes: Intensely sweet - adds a sweet malty flavor sometimes associated with honey.  Also called Brumalt.

-K0jLd8maEKtoD6KoEuQ.name: Melanoiden Malt
-K0jLd8maEKtoD6KoEuQ.notes: Aromatic malt from Banberg, Germany.  Promotes a full flavor and rounds off beer color. Promotes deep red color and malty flavor.

-K0jLd8p_EWHkKdIjzq-.name: Toasted Malt
-K0jLd8p_EWHkKdIjzq-.notes: Toasted malt can be made at home by toasting pale malted barley for 10-15 minutes at 350 F.  Similar to Biscuit or Victory malt - this malt adds reddish/orange color and improved body without sweetness.  Toasted flavor.  Mashing required to avoid haze.

-K0jLd8q3-t_7GHj0ZMW.name: Victory Malt
-K0jLd8q3-t_7GHj0ZMW.notes: Toasted malt that adds a "Biscuit" or toasted flavor to English ales. Use for: Nut brown ales, porters

-K0jLd8rgLACCsevzQb1.name: Brown Malt
-K0jLd8rgLACCsevzQb1.notes: Imparts a dry, biscuit flavor. Used in nut brown ales, porters and some Belgian ales.

-K0jLd8snqHCDHGSzAS3.name: Special Roast
-K0jLd8snqHCDHGSzAS3.notes: Use for English ales, nut brown ales and porters. Adds a toasted, biscuit like flavor and aroma

-K0jLd8snqHCDHGSzAS4.name: Aromatic Malt
-K0jLd8snqHCDHGSzAS4.notes: Provides a very strong malt flavor and aroma to your beer.

-K0jLd8trBXntbSRlydJ.name: Acid Malt
-K0jLd8trBXntbSRlydJ.notes: Acid malt contains acids from natural lactic acids.  Used by German brewers to adjust malt PH without chemicals to adhere to German purity laws.  Also enhances the head retention.

-K0jLd8trBXntbSRlydK.name: Mild Malt
-K0jLd8trBXntbSRlydK.notes: Also called "English Mild" - a light specialty malt used in Brown Ales

-K0jLd8xMrV-c2iS64l7.name: Pale Malt (2 Row) Bel
-K0jLd8xMrV-c2iS64l7.notes: Base malt for all beer styles. Higher potential yield than US, English equivalent pale ale malts

-K0jLd9-ZolHp9vOouFA.name: Pale Malt (2 Row) UK
-K0jLd9-ZolHp9vOouFA.notes: Base malt for all English beer styles. Lower diastatic power than American 2 Row Pale Malt

-K0jLd91YRBVWRyxfzur.name: Pale Malt (2 Row) US
-K0jLd91YRBVWRyxfzur.notes: Base malt for all beer styles

-K0jLd96A_61mMUj3Qqs.name: Pale Malt (6 Row) US
-K0jLd96A_61mMUj3Qqs.notes: Base malt for all beer styles

-K0jLd98RLiwO1FFR_zh.name: Pale Malt, Maris Otter
-K0jLd98RLiwO1FFR_zh.notes: Premium base malt from the UK.  Popular for many English styles of beer including ales, pale ales and bitters.

-K0jLd994ZqQFf4Jr8Xx.name: Vienna Malt
-K0jLd994ZqQFf4Jr8Xx.notes: Kiln dried malt darker than Pale Malt, but not as dark as Munich Malt. Imparts a golden to orange color to the beer.

-K0jLd9BGtVafY3E6LCU.name: Lager Malt
-K0jLd9BGtVafY3E6LCU.notes: Very light lager malt used to make Pilsners, Lagers and other light beers.  May be used as a base malt.

-K0jLd9Ddvp96HrKm-pK.name: Pilsner (2 Row) Bel
-K0jLd9Ddvp96HrKm-pK.notes: Belgian base malt for Continental lagers

-K0jLd9IFGCCJLqgDViF.name: Pilsner (2 Row) Ger
-K0jLd9IFGCCJLqgDViF.notes: German base for Pilsners and Bohemian Lagers

-K0jLd9Krcv39NKPe4Ts.name: Rice, Flaked
-K0jLd9Krcv39NKPe4Ts.notes: Used to add fermentables without increasing body or flavor. Produces a milder, less grainy tasting beer. Examples: American lagers, Bohemian lagers, Pilsners

-K0jLd9Lk5Un4V3d6TWe.name: Corn, Flaked
-K0jLd9Lk5Un4V3d6TWe.notes: Generally a neutral flavor, used to reduce maltiness of beer Produces beer with a milder, less malty flavor Uses: Primarily for light Bohemian and Pilsner lagers

-K0jLd9Lk5Un4V3d6TWf.name: Wheat Malt, Bel
-K0jLd9Lk5Un4V3d6TWf.notes: Malted wheat for use in Wheat beers

-K0jLd9N-KPrrGKfsbM2.name: Wheat Malt, Dark
-K0jLd9N-KPrrGKfsbM2.notes: Dark malted wheat base for use in dark wheat styles such as Dunkleweizen.

-K0jLd9OVKg1zHaQU1Zj.name: Wheat Malt, Ger
-K0jLd9OVKg1zHaQU1Zj.notes: Malted wheat base for use in all wheat styles

-K0jLd9OVKg1zHaQU1Zk.name: Wheat, Flaked
-K0jLd9OVKg1zHaQU1Zk.notes: Flaked wheat adds to increased body and foam retention Used in place of raw or torrified wheat for faster conversion and better yield. May be used in small amounts to improve head retention and body Examples: Belgian White beer, Wit

-K0jLd9Pf6CugLmulOzv.name: Wheat, Roasted
-K0jLd9Pf6CugLmulOzv.notes: Also called Chocolate Wheat Malt.  Kilned raw wheat - adds a deep, dark brown color to dunkelweizens and other dark beer styles. Roasted, woody, charcoal or burnt toast flavor depending on degree of roasting.

-K0jLd9Pf6CugLmulOzw.name: Wheat, Torrified
-K0jLd9Pf6CugLmulOzw.notes: Unmodified wheat that has been "popped" to open the kernels Used primarily in place of raw wheat when making Belgian White and Wit Faster conversion and higher yield than raw wheat. Protein rest recommended when mashing

-K0jLd9QQaTzsPc7Agok.name: White Wheat Malt
-K0jLd9QQaTzsPc7Agok.notes: White wheat gives a malty flavor not available from raw wheat. Used in Weiss, Wit and White beers

-K13EUAqER90zhSJE2Yu.name: Temperature Mash, 1 Step, Full Body
-K13EUAqER90zhSJE2Yu.notes: Temperature mash for use when mashing in a brew pot over a heat source such as the stove. Use heat to maintain desired temperature during mash.

-KFE7fZPOtMQ1mfJKSJT.name: Dubbel infusion, mellankropp
-KFE7fZPOtMQ1mfJKSJT.notes: Dubbel infusion - för öl med mellankropp som kräver proteinrast. Används primärt till öl med mycket omodifierad säd och tillsatser.

-K0jLd5LbyR9bt3JcKRf.name: Amylase Enzyme
-K0jLd5LbyR9bt3JcKRf.notes: Enhances fermentation and lowers final gravity by breaking down complex starches. Produces light bodied, high alcohol beers. Add when pitching yeast.

-K0jLd5OQqSQPAc2dplD.name: Anise, Star
-K0jLd5OQqSQPAc2dplD.notes: Star Anise spice adds a strong black licorice flavor to holiday and specialty beers. Boil for 30 minutes to extract flavor.

-K0jLd5P2gYXXd6eyplz.name: Apricot Extract
-K0jLd5P2gYXXd6eyplz.notes: Apricot flavor extract. Mix into beer just before bottling. Adds apricot flavor to light ales and wheat beers. Use low hop rate to allow sweet flavor through.

-K0jLd5QpZEGfgZJ3wv6.name: Ascorbic Acid
-K0jLd5QpZEGfgZJ3wv6.notes: This is Vitimin C. Adding at bottling time to wine and soda as a preservative. Not recommended for beer due to the off flavors it might add.

-K0jLd5SwGX_9FdIWH4H.name: Baking Soda
-K0jLd5SwGX_9FdIWH4H.notes: Baking Soda (NaHCO3) may be used as a water mineral to adjust brewing water for mashing.

-K0jLd5UD1uUdjyMWYto.name: Blackberry Extract
-K0jLd5UD1uUdjyMWYto.notes: Blackberry extract flavoring. Mix into beer at bottling to add berry flavor to light ales and wheat beers. Use low hop rate to allow sweet flavor through.

-K0jLd5YhHBXwtxerlSr.name: Bottle Caps
-K0jLd5YhHBXwtxerlSr.notes: Useful for bottling -- keep your inventory here.

-K0jLd5_8-FlnDGm4JWU.name: Burton Water Salts
-K0jLd5_8-FlnDGm4JWU.notes: Also known as brewing salts, it is a mixture of Gypsum, Potassium Chloride and Epsom Salt. Used to harden water.

-K0jLd5bL_AVjdacgYqn.name: Calcium Chloride
-K0jLd5bL_AVjdacgYqn.notes: Alters water profile and pH of mash. Use the BeerSmith Water Profile tool to determine amount to add.

-K0jLd5dDcWIPzyA-OGD.name: Chalk
-K0jLd5dDcWIPzyA-OGD.notes: Chalk (CaCO3) can be used as a water addition to adjust mineral content for mashing.

-K0jLd5eOIELxmd2E3CF.name: Cherry Extract
-K0jLd5eOIELxmd2E3CF.notes: Cherry extract flavoring. Mix into beer at bottling to add cherry flavor to light ales and wheat beers. Use low hop rate to allow sweet flavor through.

-K0jLd5iCn5Q2rBl1r3f.name: Cinnamon Stick
-K0jLd5iCn5Q2rBl1r3f.notes: Used to add cinnamon flavor to holiday beers. Goes well with ginger, honey and orange flavors. Add one stick 5 minutes from the end of the boil.

-K0jLd5kn8OT8ec27c7F.name: Clearfine
-K0jLd5kn8OT8ec27c7F.notes: Commercial blend of animal collagen and polysaccarides that helps rapidly precipitate yeast and tannins. Mix with 2 oz cold water and add after fermentation has completed.

-K0jLd5nj7H-zv8LsAOW.name: Coriander Seed
-K0jLd5nj7H-zv8LsAOW.notes: Used in Belgian Wit, Whites, and Holiday ales. Very good when used in light wheat ales. Often used with Bitter Orange Peel.

-K0jLd5olAUsD2PUVzhV.name: Cranberry Extract
-K0jLd5olAUsD2PUVzhV.notes: Cranberry flavor extract. Add to beer just before bottling. Adds distinctive cranberry flavor to light ales and wheat beers. Use low hop rate to allow sweet flavor through.

-K0jLd5s17Q-wuLV8umW.name: Epsom Salt (MgSO4)
-K0jLd5s17Q-wuLV8umW.notes: Water agent used to modify water profile. Use the BeerSmith Water Profile tool to determine amount to add.

-K0jLd5tqpzQzouGtI1q.name: Gale, Sweet
-K0jLd5tqpzQzouGtI1q.notes: Very strong, fragrant shrub. Great spice, though relatively unknown. Aroma used in soups, stews, and candles. Well suited for holiday beers. Use sparingly -- the aroma and flavor are VERY strong.

-K0jLd5uO9EZhpUpnSKW.name: Gelatin
-K0jLd5uO9EZhpUpnSKW.notes: Clear, unflavored gelatin can be purchased from your grocer. Aids in settling yeast. Prepare in 1 pint of water by heating gently until dissolved. Add before bottling. Do not boil.

-K0jLd5vhLTsOeI8TN-U.name: Ginger Root
-K0jLd5vhLTsOeI8TN-U.notes: Adds distinctive ginger flavor for Ginger Ales, Holiday Beers. Fresh grated ginger root from the grocer is best. As little as 1/2 ounce per 5 gallons is noticable, but up to 4 oz can be used for ginger ales.

-K0jLd5wivRUmDO6oToi.name: Gypsum (Calcium Sulfate)
-K0jLd5wivRUmDO6oToi.notes: Reduces PH of water for mashing and sparging. Alters water profile -- used to harden soft water. Use the BeerSmith Water Profile tool to determine amount to add.

-K0jLd5xGOXOQ7H9bcDf.name: Heading Liquid
-K0jLd5xGOXOQ7H9bcDf.notes: Aids head formation and retention. Mix into beer before bottling.

-K0jLd5y-Z1aKOJY56Ki.name: Irish Moss
-K0jLd5y-Z1aKOJY56Ki.notes: Fining agent that aids in the post-boil protein break. Reduces protein chill haze and improves beer clarity.

-K0jLd5zPeJvRuhfL5Sn.name: Isinglass (Liquid)
-K0jLd5zPeJvRuhfL5Sn.notes: Keep liquid form refrigerated. Isinglass is widely used by commercial brewers to aid clarity, but is not as popular for home brewers due to stability. Aids in settling proteins, tannins and yeast.

-K0jLd6-laRMfsOz3xGd.name: Lactic Acid
-K0jLd6-laRMfsOz3xGd.notes: Used to lower the pH of the mash without altering the water profile. Lower pH mashes generally improves head retention, increases extraction rate.

-K0jLd616TCvv3aiIkQ7.name: Malto-Dextrine
-K0jLd616TCvv3aiIkQ7.notes: Malt bases sugar that is less than 5% fermentable. Increases the body and mouth-feel of the beer and adds slight sweetness.

-K0jLd62wmJUXJ_cBTaf.name: Oak Chips
-K0jLd62wmJUXJ_cBTaf.notes: Can be added to the secondary or keg during aging to simulate oak flavor. Boil first to sterilize and place in weighted bag so they do not float. Amounts vary with chip size and time - smaller chips impart more flavor.

-K0jLd635cm_l0lWZXTl.name: Oak Essence (Liquid)
-K0jLd635cm_l0lWZXTl.notes: Adds Oak Aged flavor to English Ales, IPAs. Mix in prior to bottling. Amouts vary with concentration, so check label or add to taste.

-K0jLd65kfxT6mMno595.name: Orange Peel, Bitter
-K0jLd65kfxT6mMno595.notes: Made from the Curaco Orange Peel, peels are green-gray in color. Used to add a distinctive flavor to Belgian Wits and White beers.

-K0jLd66hQJ-unm-lByG.name: Orange Peel, Sweet
-K0jLd66hQJ-unm-lByG.notes: Adds a Conitreau or Grand Marnier flavor to your beer. Used primarily in Belgian Strong Ale and Holiday Ales to add a sweet orange flavor and aroma.

-K0jLd67h-t2lpA6nBOm.name: PH 5.2 Stabilizer
-K0jLd67h-t2lpA6nBOm.notes: PH 5.2 Stabilizer by Five Star is a prioprietary mix of phosphate buffers used to lower the PH of your Mash to 5.2 for brewing.

-K0jLd6AYF94_l6K0w-c.name: Papain
-K0jLd6AYF94_l6K0w-c.notes: An enzyme extracted from papaya. Helps reduce protein chill haze. Add 0.5 gram at end of secondary fermentation, allow several days for it to work. Available from herb and spice shops.

-K0jLd6AYF94_l6K0w-d.name: Polyclar
-K0jLd6AYF94_l6K0w-d.notes: Plastic powder that reduces chill haze by removing tannins and proteins. Add to secondary after yeast has settled. Amounts vary by manufacturer -- check instructions before adding. Do not boil.

-K0jLd6E7LAJS2TfdIfY.name: Raspberry Extract
-K0jLd6E7LAJS2TfdIfY.notes: Raspberry extract flavoring. Mix into beer at bottling to add berry flavor to light ales and wheat beers. Use low hop rate to allow sweet flavor through.

-K0jLd6FCKt-k7e99csA.name: Salt
-K0jLd6FCKt-k7e99csA.notes: Table Salt (NaCl) may be used as a water mineral to adjust brewing water for mashing.

-K0jLd6Gxm5Mu3lW18gm.name: Sassafras Root Bark
-K0jLd6Gxm5Mu3lW18gm.notes: Bark is safe (do not use the tree or root - they may be toxic!). This is the original source of the flavor for root beer, and adds a great root beer flavor.

-K0jLd6Gxm5Mu3lW18gn.name: Seeds of Paradise
-K0jLd6Gxm5Mu3lW18gn.notes: Also called Paradise Seeds or Grains of Paradise. Native to west Africa. Pepper zing with citrus notes, pine aroma.

-K0jLd6HV-kDtHaS8jt2.name: Spruce Extract
-K0jLd6HV-kDtHaS8jt2.notes: Spruce essence generates the flavor and smell of fresh spruce pine needles. Add in small increments and taste as it can be a rather strong flavoring.

-K0jLd6HV-kDtHaS8jt3.name: Whirlfloc Tablet
-K0jLd6HV-kDtHaS8jt3.notes: Aids in clearing yeast and chill haze. Easy to use tablet form.

-K0jLd6I0K8Vd2QvLony.name: Yeast Nutrient
-K0jLd6I0K8Vd2QvLony.notes: Gives yeast nutrients for healthy fermentation. Not needed for most beers, but good for those with a high percentage of adjuncts. Add before yeast.

-K96ZEx95mtI7TuqLr-i.name: Amber Liquid Extract
-K96ZEx95mtI7TuqLr-i.notes: Unhopped amber color liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any Ale. Examples: Amber ale, India Pale Ale, Munich style, Marzen, Bock

-K96ZH5Fl6f-A09pTOfW.name: Amber Liquid Extract
-K96ZH5Fl6f-A09pTOfW.notes: Unhopped amber color liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any Ale. Examples: Amber ale, India Pale Ale, Munich style, Marzen, Bock

-K96ZIMc-2bCFAwomDnR.name: Amber Liquid Extract
-K96ZIMc-2bCFAwomDnR.notes: Unhopped amber color liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any Ale. Examples: Amber ale, India Pale Ale, Munich style, Marzen, Bock

-K0jLdE1Z5Sm1MJqPYdr.bestFor: Belgian Trappist Ale, Spiced Ale, Trippel, Dubbel, Grand Cru
-K0jLdE1Z5Sm1MJqPYdr.name: Abbey Ale
-K0jLdE1Z5Sm1MJqPYdr.notes: Used in two of six remaining Trappist breweries. Distinctive plum and fruitiness. Good for high gravity beers.

-K0jLdE3pLRGKmXlPuq1.bestFor: American Pale Ale, Scottish Ale, Porters, Sweet Stout, Barley Wine, Alt
-K0jLdE3pLRGKmXlPuq1.name: American Ale
-K0jLdE3pLRGKmXlPuq1.notes: Soft, smooth, clean finish. Very well balanced. Very versitile -- works well with many ale styles.

-K0jLdE66woy5b25n83j.bestFor: All American Ales, Brown Ales, Barley Wine
-K0jLdE66woy5b25n83j.name: American Ale II
-K0jLdE66woy5b25n83j.notes: Clean, tart, nutty flavor. More fruity than Wyeast American Ale yeast.

-K0jLdE7rXaixREyHU2c.name: American Hefeweizen Ale
-K0jLdE7rXaixREyHU2c.notes: Produces a much smaller amount of clove and banana flavor than the German Hefeweizen White Labs yeast. Some sulfur, and creates desired cloudy look.

-K0jLdE803Wxc4JIoIS9.bestFor: All American Style Lagers -- both light and dark.
-K0jLdE803Wxc4JIoIS9.name: American Lager Yeast
-K0jLdE803Wxc4JIoIS9.notes: Dry and clean with very slight apple fruitiness. Minimal sulfer and diacetyl.

-K0jLdE9mrNHEjDRmX2_.name: American Lager
-K0jLdE9mrNHEjDRmX2_.notes: Bold, with a complex aroma. Good flavor depth characteristics for a wide variety of lager beers.

-K0jLdEAl5mujWfzvUxX.name: American Megabrewery
-K0jLdEAl5mujWfzvUxX.notes: Smooth yeast with a slight fruity flavor. Lagers into a smooth, clean tasting beer. Use for light, clean lager styles with unobtrusive yeast character.

-K0jLdEB2xw1Uu0wESsD.name: American Microbrewery Ale #1
-K0jLdEB2xw1Uu0wESsD.notes: Smooth, clean, strong fermenting ale yeast that works well at cold temperature. Clean malt flavor is ideal for cream ales.

-K0jLdEER9GgjaweMqF3.name: American Microbrewery Ale #2
-K0jLdEER9GgjaweMqF3.notes: Accentuated, rich, creamy malt profile. Generous amounts of diacytl. Use for low gravity beers where malt character is needed or stronger beers for a robust character.

-K0jLdEF7P6DPMOG3HNz.name: American Microbrewery Lager
-K0jLdEF7P6DPMOG3HNz.notes: Strong fermenter. Leaves a clean, full flavored, malty finish. Slightly attenuative. Versatile for most lager styles with a clean full flavor.

-K0jLdEG4Cpj19BV7Y3t.name: American Wheat Ale
-K0jLdEG4Cpj19BV7Y3t.notes: Dry, Crisp, tart beer in the American Hefeweizen style. Low flocculation aids in producing desired chill haze.

-K0jLdEH-h6u0YZWmx66.name: American White Ale
-K0jLdEH-h6u0YZWmx66.notes: Smooth wheat yeast with a round, clean, malt flavor. Low flocculation leaves cloudy Hefe-Weizen finish. Smooth flavor makes a great unfiltered wheat beer.

-K0jLdEJFDp3fjtnmuDQ.name: Australian Ale Yeast
-K0jLdEJFDp3fjtnmuDQ.notes: White Labs entry for Australian Ales. Produces a clean, malty finish with pleasant ester character. Bready character. Can ferment clean at high temperatures.

-K0jLdEKpVcmYyvO-jpm.bestFor: High gravity beers, Belgian ales, Dubbels, Trippels.
-K0jLdEKpVcmYyvO-jpm.name: Bastogne Belgian Ale
-K0jLdEKpVcmYyvO-jpm.notes: High gravity Trappist ale yeast. Creates a dry beer with a slightly acidic finish. Cleaner finish and slightly less spicy than WLP500 or WLP530.

-K0jLdEMwd3gKU_65ZBI.bestFor: German Bocks, Vienna, Oktoberfest, Hells, Marzens, Dunkel
-K0jLdEMwd3gKU_65ZBI.name: Bavarian Lager
-K0jLdEMwd3gKU_65ZBI.notes: Use by many German breweries. Produces a full-bodied, rich, malty beer.

-K0jLdENwcMwx81hbPEo.name: Bavarian Weizen Yeast
-K0jLdENwcMwx81hbPEo.notes: Former yeast lab W51 strain. Produces a classic German style wheat beer with moderately high, spicy, phenolic overtones reminiscent of cloves.

-K0jLdEOgYnPR9tdJ2Mq.name: Bavarian Wheat
-K0jLdEOgYnPR9tdJ2Mq.notes: Hefeweizen yeast with complex flavor and aroma. Bubble gum, banana flavors with apple/plub ester profile. Malty flavor.

-K0jLdEPM8E2AX1Wb7Jm.name: Bavarian Wheat Yeast
-K0jLdEPM8E2AX1Wb7Jm.notes: Blend of top-fermenting ale and wheat yeasts providing a mild ester and phenolic profile.

-K0jLdERlwzUo92F8MtH.bestFor: English style ales - bitter, pale, porter and brown ale
-K0jLdERlwzUo92F8MtH.name: Bedford British Ale
-K0jLdERlwzUo92F8MtH.notes: High attenuation. Ferments dry with high flocculation. Distinctive ester profile. Good for most English ale styles.

-K0jLdET6gJsO8FoTgBT.bestFor: Belgian Ales, Trappist Ales, Abbey Ales, Grand Cru
-K0jLdET6gJsO8FoTgBT.name: Belgian Abbey II
-K0jLdET6gJsO8FoTgBT.notes: Dry flavor with slight fruitiness. High alcohol tolerance.

-K0jLdEU1Hfb9li0kgiL.bestFor: Belgian Ales, Saisons, Belgian Reds, Belgian Browns, White beers
-K0jLdEU1Hfb9li0kgiL.name: Belgian Ale
-K0jLdEU1Hfb9li0kgiL.notes: Phenolic and spicy flavors. Complex profile, with less fruitiness than White's Trappist Ale strain.

-K0jLdEVJ5xnjkykeGZq.bestFor: Belgian Ales, Abbey Ales, Trappist Ales
-K0jLdEVJ5xnjkykeGZq.name: Belgian Ale Yeast
-K0jLdEVJ5xnjkykeGZq.notes: Trappist style ale yeast. Complex estery flavor.

-K0jLdEWkte3O0vnfRuc.name: Belgian Ale #1
-K0jLdEWkte3O0vnfRuc.notes: Produces classic Belgian ale flavor. Robust, estery with notes of clove and fruit. Ferments well in high gravity worts.

-K0jLdEWkte3O0vnfRud.bestFor: Flanders style Belgian Ales, Belgian Brown, Fruit beers
-K0jLdEWkte3O0vnfRud.name: Belgian Ale #2
-K0jLdEWkte3O0vnfRud.notes: Flanders style yeast. Strong fermenting yeast attenuates well and produces fruity, malty, estery malt profile. Slow to flocculate.

-K0jLdEXofUSa3YHk7g7.name: Belgian Ale #3
-K0jLdEXofUSa3YHk7g7.notes: Slightly more refined than CL-300. Produces the classic Trappist ale character with esters of spice and fruit. Mildly phenolic. Strong fermenting yeast.

-K0jLdEYNHC18M8DppHn.name: Belgian Ardennes
-K0jLdEYNHC18M8DppHn.notes: Phenolics develop at increased temperature. Mild fruitiness and complex spicy flavor.

-K0jLdEZx0Okf4-PcHU2.bestFor: Belgian Ales, Dubbel, Grand Cru, Belgian Holiday Ale
-K0jLdEZx0Okf4-PcHU2.name: Belgian Golden Ale
-K0jLdEZx0Okf4-PcHU2.notes: Combination of fruitiness and phenolic characters dominate the profile. Some sulfur which will dissapate following fermentation.

-K0jLdE_i0kCZi0c-JT8.name: Belgian Lambic Blend
-K0jLdE_i0kCZi0c-JT8.notes: Lambic culture of Saccharomyces Cerevisiar and a mixture of yeasts and bacterias. Blend of organisms helps create lactic flavor of Belgian Lambics.

-K0jLdEbHvbYcxspV79H.name: Belgian Saison
-K0jLdEbHvbYcxspV79H.notes: Classic farmhouse ale yeast. Spicy, complex aromatics including bubble gum. Tart and dry on the palate with mild fruitiness. Finishes crisp and mildly acidic. Ferment at warm temperature. May have vigorous fermentation start.

-K0jLdEe9JWagqnbYFJo.bestFor: Saison Ale, Belgian Ale, Dubbel, Trippel
-K0jLdEe9JWagqnbYFJo.name: Belgian Saison I Ale
-K0jLdEe9JWagqnbYFJo.notes: Saison yeast from Wallonia. Earthy, spicy and peppery notes. Slightly sweet.

-K0jLdEgYezBBnYev6xa.bestFor: Belgian Ales, Scottish Strong Ale,Trappist Ales, Dubbels, Trippels
-K0jLdEgYezBBnYev6xa.name: Belgian Strong Ale
-K0jLdEgYezBBnYev6xa.notes: Dry, tart, fruity flavor. High alcohol tolerance.

-K0jLdEh1As5Nb6ReFje.name: Belgian Style Ale Yeast Blend
-K0jLdEh1As5Nb6ReFje.notes: Blend of two trappist ale yeasts and one Belgian ale yeast. Creates a versatile blend to be used for Trappist and other Belgian style ales.

-K0jLdEjdQADNN5TbjVy.name: Belgian Wheat
